awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Leveraging Intensive Time Series of Accelerometer Data to Assess Impulsivity and Inattention in Preschool Children
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). This doctoral dissertation research project will develop and examine the validity of a sensor-based approach for assessing children's impulsive and inattentive behaviors. Understanding children's impulsive and inattentive behaviors is important because, even early in life, they predict later academic achievement and outcomes as diverse as employment, mental health, and substance use in adulthood. However, current methods to assess these important behaviors in real-world contexts are limited because they are subjective, imprecise, and resource intensive. This project will develop an objective, precise method of assessment with low-participant burden and the ability to assess behavior continually throughout the day. The approach developed in this project will be of value to applied researchers from a variety of fields, including education, pediatrics, and developmental and clinical psychology. Code and de-identified data from the project will be made available to the broader community. The investigators will recruit and mentor undergraduate research assistants from the diverse student body at the University of Texas at Austin.

This research project will develop and examine the validity of using wearable accelerometer devices to assess children's impulsive and inattentive behaviors in their preschool classrooms. Preschool-aged children will wear accelerometer devices while at school for one week. The devices will record data each second, capturing complex patterns of movement as children engage in classroom activities. Accelerometers are an ideal choice of sensor because children's impulsivity and inattention involve physical movement, such as getting up from one's chair, that will register as movement on the accelerometers. The analyses will use confirmatory and exploratory machine learning techniques to identify patterns in the intensive accelerometer data that index impulsivity or inattention. Analyses will go beyond the commonly used summaries of movement from accelerometers and instead take advantage of the rich patterns of movement that such summaries discard. The investigators will validate the accelerometer approach against existing measures of children's impulsivity and inattention. These results of this project will facilitate applied research and enhance our understanding of children's behavior in their real-world environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to produce and evaluate a novel measurement technique to assess children's inattentive and impulsive behaviors in their everyday settings. This goal was accomplished. Over the funding period, the project supported data collection and produced several outcomes: 

1) A dataset with high-intensity actigraphy data, teacher and parent questionnaires, and direct assessmets. Other researchers can request this dataset from the investigators. 

2) A dissertation that will become publicly available through the Texas Digital Respository. 

3) One publication in a leading pediatric journal, JAMA pediatrics titled "Ambient temperatures increases and preschoolers’ outdoor physical activity"

4) A manuscript that is currently under review (revise and resubmit) at the leading developmental journal, Child Development, titled "Leveraging an intensive time series of young children’s movement to capture impulsive and inattentive behaviors in a preschool setting."

5) Mentored a diverse group of eight undrgraduate research assistants who gained firsthand research experience by collecting data for this project. 

6) Produced code to process and generate time series variables that indicate impulsive and inattentive behaviors from young children. Other researchers can request this code from the investigators. 

This award supported the doctoral candidate in completing his dissertation (defended in May 2023) and disseminating his findings at the biennial meeting of the Society for Research in Child Development in March 2023. The dissertation is summarized as follows: 

Children’s self-regulation is a fundamental skill for success in school. To engage constructively in a lesson, children must be able to calm their bodies, ignore distractions, and inhibit the impulse to do something else. Parents and teachers are often concerned with day-to-day variability in young children’s behavior as they prepare for formal schooling, but within-child fluctuations are under-studied despite obvious relevance for educational practice and classroom management. This gap results, in part, from the difficulty in collecting repeated observations of children’s behavior.

In the dissertation, I tested and applied a novel approach for capturing repeated observations of children’s self-regulation in a preschool setting. I used wearable accelerometers that capture movement to assess impulsive and inattentive behaviors targeted by commonly used measures of self-regulation. Using the intensive time series of data provided by the wearable devices, I generated hundreds of variables that characterized dimensions of children’s reactivity including movement amount, onset, intensity, duration, and changes in intensity while at school. Using machine learning methods to analyze the high-volume dataset, I found that children’s typical acceleration at movement onset was strongly predictive of teacher reports of children’s impulsivity, inhibitory control, and attention at school.

I then partitioned the intensive time series of movement data to understand children’s behavior during specific periods. I found that 1) children modulated their behavior to meet expectations for different parts of the school day, 2) children showed greater impulsivity as the school week progressed, and 3) children with greater self-regulation showed greater consistency in applying it across days. We were recently invited to revise and resubmit this publication at Child Development, the flagship journal of my field.

Using data from my dissertation project, we also recently co-authored a paper with colleagues to examine how heat impacts young children’s physical activity outdoors. Using within-child comparisons, we found that during play periods with high ambient temperatures, children spent more time being sedentary, and less time in moderate to vigorous physical activity. The manuscript reporting these findings was recently accepted at JAMA Pediatrics, a leading pediatric journal (Koepp, Lanza et al., 2023).

 

 


Last Modified: 11/10/2023
Modified by: Andrew E Koepp
